content:
Should be fixable. Let‚Äôs take a look together. Here‚Äôs how we're going to try to to reattach your old Thunderbird profile:

Step 1. Find the old profile

You‚Äôve already done this, just do it agian and double-check that it contains the following: 

*   A Mail or ImapMail folder 
*   Files like prefs.js, key4.db, logins.json, abook.sqlite, etc.

(If that‚Äôs all there: Terrific. That‚Äôs your profile)


Step 2. Launch Thunderbird Profile Manager

Make sure Thunderbird is fully closed (no background processes).

Then Press Windows + R. type: thunderbird.exe -p. 

(and then press. Enter - this will open the profile manager)

Click Create Profile On the next screen, click ‚ÄúChoose Folder‚Ä¶‚Äù and browse to the exact folder on your other HDD that holds your old profile (this should be the folder that contains prefs.js, not one above it) Finish the setup 

In the list, select your new profile and check the box that should say something like ‚ÄúUse the selected profile without asking at startup‚Äù

Then Click Start Thunderbird

If everything is in the right place, Thunderbird should launch with all your old emails, settings, address book, etc. back.

ü§û

Let me know if the worked!
creator: Thundamike

Lex

content:
Sorry to hear that. But, there's a couple things to try here. Let‚Äôs roll up our sleeves and hopefully fix this for you.

1. Try compacting folders

  • Go to your email account > right-click a folder like Inbox or Trash > Compact. This cleans up ‚Äúdeleted‚Äù space and can improve speed - especially if it's been some time since this action was performed.

2. What kind of email account is this?

  • If it‚Äôs an IMAP account (like Gmail, Yahoo, Proton via Bridge, etc.), Thunderbird has to sync the deletion with the server. If the server is slow or there's a lot of back-and-forth, then that slow communication can cause delays.

3. Are you using Proton Mail with Proton Bridge?

  • Proton Bridge can sometimes slow down when handling bulk actions like deleting multiple messages, especially if Proton's under heavy load

content:
You were right to be suspicious, You definitely should not need to install an older version of Thunderbird to get your Outlook emails working.

Okie-doke, let‚Äôs roll up our sleeves and fix this. Since you're seeing the first message from your Outlook account but not the newer ones, let's try this first:

Confirm IMAP Setting in t-bird

  • Go to Account Settings in Thunderbird
  • Select your new Outlook account and check the 'Server Settings'
  • IMAP server settings should be: 
        *   imap-mail.outlook.com,          *  Port: 993,          *  SSL: SSL/TLS         *  Authentication Type = Normal Password (most likely)

Then go to Thunderbird -> Account Settings -> Edit Outgoing Server

  • smtp-mail.outlook.com,
  • Port: 587,
  • STARTTLS


Let me know if this helped!

content: I hope my comment helps: you are viewing the same account through two different windows. what you see on the POP account are messages downloaded to your PC. What you see on the IMAP account folders are messages that are on the server and downloaded to your PC ONLY for your viewing. So, POP messages are no longer tied to the server and deleting the POP account does not affect folders and messages on the server. If you delete messages appearing on your PC of the IMAP account, the copy on PC is deleted and also the copy on server. So, on your question, deleting the POP account does not affect messages on the server. BUT, messages MOVED from IMAP account to LOCAL FOLDERS are still part of the IMAP account. Your post makes it unclear on what messages are moved from where to where.

content: My suggestion is this: - create the desired folders in your online account, not via Thunderbird - since IMAP not designed for massive uploads, getting messages uploaded will always be problematic - I suggest copying in small groups, folder by folder. It is a gardening project, done little by little. thunderbird is not 'doing' anything, but is acting as a conductor, directing internet server to upload a message at a time and the server is also serving thousands of other users while doing that. if you want to be rid of the POP account, you could create a new Local Folder called OLDPOP. Then, exit thunderbird, and in profile folder, locate the POP account in the Mail folder, such as Mail\<POPaccountname> and COPY the entire contents and save in the Mail\Local Folders\OLDPOP folder. Then restart thunderbird and check carefully that you copied everything. You can now delete the POP account and continue your project of getting all content safely uploaded.

content:
Ok, by online account, I am referring to logging on to your IMAP account at your email provide's website. That is the place to define the folders. Thunderbird will recognize them after you create them. Once defined, you may, in thunderbird, need to click synchronization&storage for the account to verify that they're ok for offline use.

Now, create the OLDPOP folder in thunderbird. Then, click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'. You will then be in the profile. Note it's drive location, which is probably at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles\<yourprofilename> IF THIS IS NOT TRUE, stop and let me know. Next, exit thunderbird, you are now in the profile in Windows File Explorer. Your POP account is in the Mail folder as Mail\<yourPOPaccountname> In that folder, you should see files such as inbox, inbox.msf, sent, sent.msf etc. that folder should represent your many folders. If unsure, please post a screenshot. If I'm right, then COPY the entire contents of that folder and paste into the Mail\Local Folders\OLDPOP folder that you created and then restart thunderbird and let me know status.

content:
My apologies. I'm getting you confused My suggestion about OLDPOP was a temporary means to save the POP files and remove the POP account. I regret having made the suggestion. Please just forget all about OLDPOP. We do not need it on your online account. Let's proceed without it.

  1. first, you create a folder on the server for each POP account you want to be there. I think you said that's been done
  2. now, one-by-one, highlight and COPY all messages from a POP folder to its corresponding online folder. If this is too cumbersome, I suggest creating a manual filter to copy the entire folder contents
  3. after copying all folders, do a thorough review to ensure that you have all the messages copied. Uploading to IMAP is problematic, so a review would be prudent
  4. once you're content, you can remove the POP account. (but if you're a bit nervous about that, do a full copy of the folders elsewhere.

As a side comment, I encourage you to learn how to access the IMAP account online, as there may be times when you need to. Most email providers even recommend that access and provide a login button for that purpose.

content:
here are the normal steps: let me know the steps you took and that will help in resolving your issue.

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

your steps will probably different. Once you share in whatever detail you remember, we can assist.

content:
I would not expect this to clear up on its own.

Proxies and VPNs can cause such problems. Also, Is your computer managed by your employer, school, or another organization?

To diagnose ... check the update debug log and other update files:

  1. Settings > General > Config Editor (https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/config-editor)
  2. Paste in app.update.log and set it to true
  3. Open the Console either with the hotkey Control+Shift+J (Command+Shift+J on macOS), or via Hamburger Menu->Tools->Developer Tools->Console
  4. Near the top, in the text field "Filter Output", enter AUS: to select just messages related to updates. Check that Logs is highlighted at "Errors Warnings Logs".
  5. In Settings' search field type or paste "updates", then click on the button "Update to xxx" or "Check for Updates"
  6. Once the update check has completed, copy the messages out of the Console and attach them here.
  7. In same area of Settings click the button "Show Update History" and screen shot it
  8. If the update process began and is being investigated, do Help > Troubleshooting Information to find "Update Folder", click "Open Folder" or "Show in Finder" and expand that directory to find last-update.log, last-update.log and backup-update.log and attach

content:
I have windows 11 Pro 23H2 and 24H2 (which is 10.0.26100 ) and thunderbird update work fine.

My guess : the problem could be your PC itself or Thunderbird installation on your PC.

Suggestion : uninstall Thunderbird and re-install the latest version and retry the update.

Open Thunderbird Error console while retry the update to see if any error message would show up. ( to open Thunderbird Error console : position your mouse on Thunderbird and then press ctrl + shift + j )

content:
Ci sono un paio di segnalazioni simili, potrebbe essere un bug.

Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content:
To ensure full compatibility for the transfer, you could uninstall 141 completely and install 115 on the new computer from here: 

https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/115.18.0/win64/en-US/

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

That 'identical' reference
creator: davidsk

content:
David, Thanks for your prompt reply. Presumably, after I install 115.8.0 version on the new Windows 11 computer and do the email transfer then Thunderbird will automatically update the new computer version to the most current version for Windows 11 - is that correct?

Also, I'm not a Thunderbird expert so maybe you can tell me, when I do the Appdata\roaming folder transfer to the new computer does that transfer set up the same Thunderbird connection to my email service (AOL)? That is, does all the port info, usernames, passwords that my old Thunderbird used to reach my AOL mail automatically carry over to the new computer so that I don't have to do all that again? Does my question make sense? - Chris
creator: cvancant

content: on first question, no. you will have click the update button on second question, the transfer is 100% - all data and account settings and passwords are transferred. Some email providers require setting new passwords for a different computer, but I don't think AOL has that requirement.

content:
Puzzling, since all you did was copy. I suggest going to old computer, click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profiles and click 'about:profiles' Now, there may be more than one profile listed, click the 'open folder' on each. Check the default folder first. Once in the folder, open the Mail folder for info on a POP account. click the folder with account name In that folder, do you see folders such as inbox, inbox.msf, sent, sent.msf, etc? If so, those are possibly your missing messages Do the same for all profile folders, comparing size and last date updated.

If you see any possibilities, let me know. Often, messages appear lost when they are just in a different profile.

content:
Ok, let's start salvage.

  1. on the new computer, start thunderbird and create the POP account, but do NOT enter password yet, as we do not want to have it bring in any messages yet.
  2. now, exit thunderbird
  3. in windows file explorer, COPY your Mail\pop.gmail.com folder from old pc to overwrite the same folder in the new computer.
  4. also, copy the abook.sqlite and history.sqlite from the old pc profile to the same place in new pc profile. that will prompt for overwrite. that should restore the addressbook
  5. now, restart thunderbird and enter password and the account should now work.
  6. now, install the addon, importexporttools NG.
  7. next, highlight Local Folders
  8. now, rightclick and select the importexport option to import mbox
  9. on the screen that opens, select the Mail\Local Folders folder on old pc's profile and select one of the folders (ignore msf entries)
  10. repeat the above for each folder in Local Folders
  11. when done, all of the local folders should now be visible.
  12. now, let me know status.
